messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>

> What were the very serious problems?
> They [first Shavian ligatures]look to me just like
> mandatory ligatures.
>

Ah, but the Shavian compound-letters are not ligatures but effectively
letters in their own right. The QS arrangement are closer to being
ligatures. The design for first Shavian "ligatures" can be described
like this:

"When one hears a sound pair first try to find a compound-letter for
it and only if none exist then use the separate letters."

Where rhotics hear certain vowels + R they choose a Shavian "ligature"
and where non-rhotics hear vowel + /@/ they choose the same ligature.
Unfortunately non-rhotics still use that same ligature even when
rhotics have vowel + /@/ thus inserting Rs into words where nobody has
them.
So to correct this, Shavian still has to add a rule about Rs to the
effect:
"use the appropriate ligature only when the word has an R spoken by
most people."
But if you still have to have a rule like this, the original reason
for the ligatures disappears.

In QS we have a simpler rule: "write out all Rs when they are spoken
by most people."
Further more, when mistakes occurs they will tend more often to be
omitted Rs rather than extra inserted Rs and this too is an advantage.

But I really don't want to deprecate these "ligatures" too much, there
may very well be a way to use them in a very productive way augmenting
or differing from the first Shaw alphabet. Certainly we seem to be
heading rapidly down this path.


You may notice also that I perpetual put quotes around the word
"ligature". This is because what we are talking about not ligatures
but letters.
- Typographically they are redundant being identical to those same
letters with tight kerning.
- In at least one case (the NURSE set), when we assigned a lexical
set to a "ligature", it really ceased being one, the sound now
differing from the combined sounds of the component letters.
- The talk of an extra key press to trigger or suppress a ligature is
really an elaborate form of dead-key press for a separate letter. And
Paul seems sensibly to want a single key press for what instinctively
feels like a letter.
